page-eth2-scalable-desc: Ethereum needs to support 1000s of transactions per second, to make applications faster and cheaper to use.
page-eth2-secure-desc: Ethereum needs to be more secure. As the adoption of Ethereum grows, the protocol needs to become more secure against all forms of attack.
page-eth2-sustainable-desc: Ethereum needs to be better for the environment. The technology today requires too much computing power and energy.
page-eth2-beacon-chain-desc: The first Eth2 addition to the ecosystem. The Beacon Chain brings staking to Ethereum, lays the groundwork for future upgrades, and will eventually coordinate the new system.
page-eth2-beacon-chain-date: The Beacon Chain went live on December 1, 2020.
page-eth2-shard-desc: Shard chains will expand Ethereum's capacity to process transactions and store data. The shards themselves will gain more features over time, rolled out in multiple phases.
page-eth2-shard-date: The introduction of shard chains, the second upgrade, is expected some time in 2021.
page-eth2-docking-desc: Mainnet Ethereum will need to “dock” or “merge” with the Beacon Chain at some point. This will enable staking for the entire network and signal the end of energy-intensive mining.
page-eth2-docking-answer-1: The docking is when mainnet turns into a shard. This will come after a successful implementation of shard chains.
page-eth2-meta-desc: An overview of the Ethereum 2.0 upgrades and the vision they hope to make a reality.
page-eth2-upgrade-desc: The Ethereum we know and love, just more scalable, more secure, and more sustainable...
page-eth2-whats-eth2-desc: Eth2 refers to a set of interconnected upgrades that will make Ethereum more scalable, more secure, and more sustainable. These upgrades are being built by multiple teams from across the Ethereum ecosystem.
page-eth2-what-to-do: What do you need to do?
page-eth2-what-to-do-desc: If you're a dapp user or ETH holder, you don't need to do anything. If you're a developer or want to start staking, there are ways you can get involved today.
page-eth2-vision-desc: To bring Ethereum into the mainstream and serve all of humanity, we have to make Ethereum more scalable, secure, and sustainable.
page-eth2-the-upgrades-desc: Eth2 is a set of upgrades that improve the scalability, security, and sustainability of Ethereum. Although each is being worked on in parallel, they have certain dependencies that determine when they will be deployed.
page-eth2-help-desc: There’s plenty of opportunities to weigh in on the Eth2 upgrades, help with testing, and even earn rewards in the process.
page-eth2-unofficial-roadmap: This is not the official roadmap. This is how we view what’s happening based on the information out there. But this is technology, things can change in an instant. So please don’t read this as a commitment.
page-eth2-dive-desc: How are we going to make Ethereum more scalable, secure, and sustainable? All while keeping Ethereum's core ethos of decentralization.
page-eth2-index-staking-desc: Key to the Eth2 upgrades is the introduction of staking. If you want to use your ETH to help secure the Ethereum network, make sure you follow these steps.
page-eth2-index-staking-step-1-desc: To stake in Eth2 you’ll need to use the launchpad – this will walk you through the process.
page-eth2-index-staking-step-2-desc: Before you stake your ETH, be sure to check you’ve got the right address. You must have gone through the launchpad before doing this.
page-eth2-index-staking-learn-desc: The beacon chain will bring staking to Ethereum. This means if you have ETH, you can do a public good by securing the network and earn more ETH in the process.
page-eth2-question-1-desc: Eth2 is a set of distinct upgrades with different ship dates.
page-eth2-question-2-desc: It’s not accurate to think of Eth2 as a separate blockchain.
page-eth2-answer-1: Think of Eth2 as a set of upgrades being added to improve the Ethereum we use today. These upgrades include the creation of a new chain called the beacon chain and up to 64 chains known as shards.
page-eth2-answer-2: These are separate to the Ethereum mainnet we use today but won’t replace it. Instead mainnet will dock or 'merge' with this parallel system that’s being added over time.
page-eth2-answer-4: In other words the Ethereum we use today will eventually embody all the features that we’re aiming towards in the Eth2 vision.
page-eth2-question-3-desc: You don't have to do anything right now to prepare for Eth2.
page-eth2-question-3-title: How do I prepare for Eth2?
page-eth2-question3-answer-1: Eth holders certainly don't need to do anything. Your ETH will not need changing or upgrading. There's almost certain to be scams telling you otherwise, so be careful.
page-eth2-question-3-answer-2: The shard chain and docking upgrades may impact dapp developers. But the specifications have not been finalised yet, so there's no immediate action required.
page-eth2-question-3-answer-3: Talk to the Eth2 research and development team over at ethresear.ch.
page-eth2-question-4-desc: Eth1 refers to the Ethereum mainnet you transact on today.
page-eth2-question-4-answer-1: Whenever you send a transaction or use a dapp today, you're using Eth1. This is the Ethereum that is secured by miners.
page-eth2-question-4-answer-2: 'Eth1', or mainnet, will continue to run as normal until the docking.
page-eth2-question-4-answer-3: After the docking, validators will secure the entire network via proof-of-stake.
page-eth2-question-4-answer-6: Anyone can become a validator by staking their ETH.
page-eth2-question-4-answer-8: The Beacon Chain and shard chain upgrades will not disrupt Eth1 as they are being built out separately.
page-eth2-question-5-desc: You’ll need to use the staking launchpad or join a staking pool.
page-eth2-question-5-answer-1: To become a full validator on the network, you'll need to stake 32 ETH. If you don't have that much, or aren't willing to stake that much, you can join staking pools. These pools will let you stake less and earn fractions of the total rewards.
page-eth2-question-6-desc: Your dapp won’t be affected by any imminent upgrades. However future upgrades may require some changes.
page-eth2-question-6-title: What do I need to do with my dapp?
page-eth2-question-6-answer-1: For now, there's no actions to take. But we recommend you stay up to date with developments on the shard chains and the docking upgrades.
page-eth2-question-6-answer-3: Danny Ryan of the Ethereum foundation regularly updates the community:
page-eth2-question-6-answer-4: Ben Edginton of ConsenSys has a weekly Eth2 newsletter:
page-eth2-question-6-answer-5: You can also join the discussion on Eth2 research and development at ethresear.ch.
page-eth2-question-7-desc: Many different teams from all over the community are working on the various Eth2 upgrades.
page-eth2-question-8-desc: The Ethereum we use today needs to offer a better experience to end users and network participants.
page-eth2-question-8-answer-1: The Eth2 upgrades will help Ethereum scale in a decentralized way, while maintaining security, and increasing sustainability.
page-eth2-question-8-answer-2: Perhaps the most obvious problem is that Ethereum needs to be able to handle more than 15-45 transactions per second. But the Eth2 upgrades also address some other problems with Ethereum today.
page-eth2-question-8-answer-3: The network is in such high demand that it's making Ethereum expensive to use. Nodes in the network are struggling under the size of Ethereum and the amount of data their computers are having to process. And the underlying algorithm that keeps Ethereum secure and decentralized is energy intensive and needs to be greener.
page-eth2-question-8-answer-4: A lot of what's changing has always been on the Ethereum roadmap, even since 2015. But current conditions are making the need for the upgrades even greater.
page-eth2-question-9-desc: You don't have to be technical to contribute. The community is looking for contributions from all kinds of skillsets.
page-eth2-question-9-title: How can I contribute to Eth2?
page-eth2-question-9-answer-1: The most active role you can play is to stake your ETH.
page-eth2-question-9-answer-2: You may also want to run a second client to help improve client diversity.
page-eth2-question-9-answer-3: If you're more technical, you can help catch bugs in the new clients.
page-eth2-question-9-answer-4: You can also weigh in on the technical discussions with Ethereum researchers at ethresear.ch.
page-eth2-question-10-desc: Phases relate to phases of work and focus in the Eth2 technical roadmap.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-1: We're reluctant to talk too much in terms of a technical roadmap because this is software: things can change. We think it's easier to understand what's happening when you read about the outcomes.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-2: But if you've followed the discussions, here's how the upgrades fit into technical roadmaps.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-3: Phase 0 describes the work to get the Beacon Chain live.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-5: Phase 1 of technical roadmaps focus on implementing the shard chains.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-6: Docking mainnet into Eth2 is an extension of the work done to implement shard chains and has been referred to as Phase 1.5. But it's a significant moment as the Ethereum we know today merges with the other Eth2 upgrades. Plus it's when Ethereum fully transitions to proof of stake.
page-eth2-question-10-answer-7: It's currently unclear what will happen around Phase 2. It's still a point of intense research and discussion. The initial plan was to add extra functionality to the shard chains but it might not be necessary with a rollup-centric roadmap.
page-eth2-stay-up-to-date-desc: Get the latest from the researchers and developers working on the Eth2 upgrades.
page-eth2-take-part-desc: Ethereum researchers and enthusiasts alike meet here to discuss research efforts, including everything Eth2.
eth2-rhino-img-alt: Graphic of Eth 2 Rhino charging ahead
page-eth2-diagram-p: Ethereum mainnet will continue to exist in its current form for a while. This means the Beacon Chain and shard upgrades won't disrupt the network.
page-eth2-diagram-p-1: Mainnet will eventually merge with the new system introduced by the Eth2 upgrades.
page-eth2-diagram-p-2: The Beacon Chain will become the conductor of Ethereum, coordinating validators and setting the pace for block creation.
page-eth2-diagram-p-3: At first, it will exist separately from mainnet and manage validators – it will have nothing to do with smart contracts, transactions, or accounts.
page-eth2-diagram-p-4: Shards will provide lots of extra data to help increase the amount of transactions mainnet can handle. They'll be coordinated by the Beacon Chain.
page-eth2-diagram-p-5: But all transactions will still rely on mainnet, which will continue to exist as we know it today – secured by proof-of-work and miners.
page-eth2-diagram-p-6: Mainnet will merge with the proof-of-stake system, coordinated by the Beacon Chain.
page-eth2-diagram-p-8: This will turn mainnet into a shard within the new system. Miners will no longer be needed as all of Ethereum will be secured by validators.
page-eth2-diagram-p10: Eth2 is not a migration or a single thing. It describes a set of upgrades being worked on to unlock Ethereum's true potential. This is how they all fit together.
page-eth2-diagram-scroll: Scroll to explore – tap for more information.
